column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: Since 2011, Dexus has conducted periodic group-wide physical climate risk assessments to determine the magnitude of climate risks across the portfolio. Properties identified as high risk through the portfolio-wide climate risk assessment have site-specific climate risk assessments to evaluate significant climate-related vulnerabilities and adaptation actions.
column20: Physical climate risk assessment, climate risk, climate-related vulnerability

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: Dexus has a Climate Resilience Working Group responsible for monitoring climate-related risks and opportunities relevant to the group and coordinating climate-related management activities.
column20: Climate Resilience Working Group, climate-related risk, climate-related management

column6: Defined benefit plan obligations and other retirement plans
column7: Dexus does not operate a defined benefit superannuation scheme. Consistent with Australian legislation, superannuation contributions are made to superannuation funds employees select. Dexus contributes retirement provisions in line with Australia's employer superannuation guarantee requirements.
Dexus did not undertake any Energy Saving Certificate (ESC) transactions, resulting in $0 revenue for the year.

column6: Ratios of standard entry level wage by gender compared to local minimum wage
Proportion of senior management hired from the local community

column13: Dexus implements a smart buildings delivery strategy and model to build transparency around minimum standards for technology requirements and data infrastructure. This approach means challenges relating to technology compatibility, and future-proofing can be addressed. This new process has identified financial and operational benefits for Dexus' Waterfront Brisbane project.
column20: Smart building delivery strategy, data infrastructure, technology compatibility

column13: Dexus trialled bipolar ionisation to enhance indoor air quality; however, this yielded limited commercial benefits above the high levels of existing indoor environment quality. Dexus progressed future readiness for the rollout of mobile access for its customers, driven by the need for a standardised approach to mobile access and wallet features.
column20: Bipolar ionisation, indoor air quality, indoor environment quality

column13: Dexus is proud to have brought Australia's oldest theatre institution back to life with the launch of Theatre Royal Sydney at 25 Martin Place. As part of a vibrant new precinct, the rejuvenated lyric theatre is attracting a range of new shows to Sydney, boosting the economy and extending night-time entertainment options for the community.
column20: Theatre Royal Sydney, lyric theatre, night-time entertainment

column13: At the Waterfront Brisbane project, Dexus engaged Blaklash as a First Nations Design Consultant in a cultural visioning capacity. Blaklash's engagement has focused on opportunities to Design with Country to ensure culturally relevant and integrated placemaking strategies are expressed throughout the development. Given the scale of the project, it is anticipated that further work will be required to ensure community engagement and a co-design process enacted to allow Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture to be represented throughout the built environment at Waterfront Brisbane.
column20: Blaklash, First Nations Design Consultant, placemaking strategy

column13: Dexus' partnership with the Black Dog Institute focuses on creating a mentally healthier world. The partnership has promoted the Black Dog Institute's programs and content across Dexus's customer base through lift screens, events, and wider communications to help reduce the stigma and support mental health in the workplace. The programs included the NSW Government initiative for free business mental health training and the MyCompass online self-help program.\t
column20: Black Dog Institute, mental health, self-help program

column13: Across its retail centres, Dexus focused on serving its communities and localising activations to create compelling experiences within its spaces. Dexus' activations throughout FY23 included the Adopt-a-pet initiative at Willows Shopping Centre, where half of the revenue was returned to a pet rehoming not-for-profit, and a ticketed dinner event at Casula Shopping Centre to celebrate Eid al-Fitr and the end of Ramadan.
column20: Adopt-a-pet initiative, community, Willows Shopping Centre

column13: This year, Dexus' employees took part in community volunteering events across Australia, including the Eat Up Australia Sandwich challenge, Cerebral Palsy Alliance's STEPtember and Christmas present wrapping, and the Balmoral Swim, where Dexus' sponsorship raised funds for the Children's Cancer Institute.
column20: Volunteering, Eat Up Australia Sandwich challenge, STEPtember

column13: Dexus has a Social Impact Working Group, which implements the group's social impact strategy across communities, people, customers, and suppliers.
column20: Social Impact Working Group, social impact strategy, community

column13: Dexus has a Reconciliation Action Plan Working Group, responsible for advancing the group's reconciliation journey with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and implementing initiatives aligned with Dexus's Reconciliation Action Plan.
column20: Reconciliation Action Plan Working Group, reconciliation journey, RAP

column6: Proportion of spending on local suppliers
column13: This year, Dexus engaged ARA Indigenous Services in a competitive tender exercise for cleaning services in Industrial and health assets in NSW, QLD and VIC. ARA Indigenous Services is creating community impact by supporting Indigenous youth through work placement, social procurement initiatives and educational opportunities.
column20: ARA Indigenous Services, community impact, Indigenous youth

column6: Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
column13: The group strongly supports identifying and disclosing corrupt conduct, illegality or substantial waste of company assets under its Whistleblower Policy. Employees who make such disclosures are protected from any detrimental action or reprisal, and an independent external disclosure management service provider has been appointed to ensure, when requested, anonymity for those reporting incidents.
column20: Whistleblower Policy, corrupt conduct, external disclosure management

column6: Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column13: During the year, all employees received communication and completed training about policies and procedures related to fraud, anti-corruption and human rights. Employees are required to declare their compliance with Dexus's Code of Conduct annually. Anti-corruption policies and procedures are included as part of this compliance. Compliance training is compulsory for every employee.

column6: Confirmed incidents of corruption and actions taken
column7: Dexus had no cases of corruption in 2023.

column6: Legal actions for anti-competitive behavior, anti-trust, and monopoly practices
column7: No legal actions were brought against Dexus for anti-competitive, anti-trust, or monopoly practices in FY23.

column6: Reductions in energy requirements of products and services
column13: Dexus has an Energy Procurement Working Group, which is responsible for implementing a group-wide energy procurement approach and coordinating ongoing procurement practices for electricity and natural gas while integrating a transition to clean energy.

column6: Interactions with water as a shared resource
column7: Dexus has a well-established NABERS program to benchmark energy and water performance nationally, using a rating scale from 1 to 6 stars.

Overall, Dexus' office properties have maintained their NABERS Energy ratings despite increasing physical occupancy, and its office portfolio has achieved a 9.5% reduction in energy intensity in FY23 versus its 2019 baseline. Water intensity is higher this year compared to FY22 in response to greater physical occupancy, yet it remains well below Dexus' 2019 baseline, with a 34.6% reduction since 2019.
Dexus withdrew 1,326,775 kL of water in 2023.
Dexus' water intensity was 0.47 kL per sqm of office area.
